item.title: Highly Cited Researcher 2025
item.description:
We are honored to announce that Gioele La Manno has been recognized as a Highly Cited Researcher for 2025 by Clarivate Analytics.

For the third consecutive year, this recognition acknowledges the significant influence and impact of our research. This distinction is awarded to roughly 1 in 1,000 researchers globally whose publications are among the most frequently cited, reflecting sustained and broad impact in their field.

Thank you to all our collaborators, lab members, and the broader research community for their support and engagement with our work.

item.title: Lipid Brain Atlas preprint released
item.description:
We are excited to announce the release of our preprint “The Lipidomics Architecture of the Mouse Brain” on bioRxiv!

This work represents a major milestone for our lab, presenting the first comprehensive spatial lipidomic atlas of the adult mouse brain. Using high-resolution MALDI mass spectrometry imaging, we mapped 172 membrane lipids across 109 sections and 11 brains, all registered to the Allen Brain Atlas.

Key findings: - We identified 539 spatially coherent biochemical domains, which we call “lipizones” - Lipizones capture both neuronal cell bodies and their distal terminals - White matter shows marked regional heterogeneity driven by oligodendrocyte-specific lipids - We discovered that pregnancy induces coordinated lipid remodeling in the cortex and white matter

This atlas establishes lipids as an important and previously unexplored axis of molecular brain architecture. The preprint is currently in revision at Nature.

Read the preprint: bioRxiv

item.title: The Lipidomics Architecture of the Mouse Brain
Antonio Herrera appointed Group Leader
item.description:
We are proud to announce that Dr. Antonio Herrera, a postdoctoral researcher in our lab since 2021, has been awarded a prestigious Ramón y Cajal fellowship!

Toni will start his own research group at the University of Granada, Spain, in the second half of 2026.

During his time in the La Manno Lab, Toni has made fundamental contributions to our research program, including developing computational methods for spatial transcriptomics analysis and contributing to multiple high-impact publications. His work on deep learning methods for imaging and spatial biology has been particularly impactful.

We are excited to see Toni establish his own independent research program and look forward to future collaborations. Congratulations Toni!

Congratulations Dr. Irina Khven!
item.description:
We are delighted to announce that Irina Khven has successfully defended her PhD thesis!

Irina’s thesis, “Fine-grained mapping of neural progenitors subtypes in the embryonic brain unveils context-dependent roles of signalling on cell fate decisions,” represents a major contribution to our understanding of brain development.

During her PhD in the EDNE program (2019-2025), Irina made fundamental contributions to mapping neural progenitor diversity using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell approaches. Her work has been instrumental in establishing the lab’s spatial transcriptomics capabilities and generating some of the most comprehensive datasets on embryonic brain development.

Irina will continue her scientific career as a Postdoctoral researcher at the Institute of Molecular and Clinical Ophthalmology Basel (IOB).

Congratulations Dr. Khven, and best wishes for your future research!

Zeiss IDEAS Grant awarded
item.description:
We are excited to announce that we have been awarded a Zeiss IDEAS grant!

This CHF 100,000 grant (Mar 2025 - Feb 2026) will support our research on “Neural Interpolation of 3D Distributions from Sections” - developing computational methods to reconstruct volumetric molecular distributions from 2D tissue section data.

This project builds on our expertise in spatial transcriptomics and will advance our capabilities for building 3D molecular atlases of brain development.

item.title: ERC Starting Grant MOVIOLA awarded
item.description:
We are thrilled to announce that the La Manno Lab has been awarded a European Research Council (ERC) Starting Grant for the project “MOVIOLA: Cell decision capture and control via joint Raman live and omics profiling.”

This 5-year grant (Feb 2026 - Jan 2031, 1.5 million euros) will support our research into understanding the molecular determinants that govern neural cell fate decisions during human brain development.

The MOVIOLA project introduces a novel experimental paradigm that combines live Raman microscopy with multi-modal molecular profiling to capture cells at the precise moments when fate decisions occur. We will develop the “Rewind, Halt & Edit” methodology, which enables:

  • Retrospective identification of decision points through continuous cellular monitoring
  • Targeted profiling at critical moments
  • Temporal manipulation of decision factors

Using human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived neural systems, we aim to identify the specific molecular factors—including transcription cascades, signaling pathways, metabolic states, and lipid compositions—that drive individual fate choices.

The ERC Starting Grant is one of the most prestigious and competitive funding schemes for early-career researchers in Europe, and we are grateful for this opportunity to advance our research program.

item.title: SNSF Spark Grant 2025
item.description:
We are pleased to announce that we have been awarded an SNSF Spark grant!

This CHF 100,000 grant (Jan 2025 - Dec 2026) will support our project “Charting the Individuality of Neural Progenitor State Transition Sequences by Hyperspectral Time-lapse Imaging.”

This exploratory project will develop new approaches to track individual neural progenitor cells as they make fate decisions, combining live imaging with computational analysis to understand the temporal dynamics of neural differentiation.

item.title: SNSF R'Equip Grant for MALDI Imaging System
item.description:
We are pleased to announce that we have been awarded an SNSF R’Equip grant for the acquisition of a next-generation MALDI imaging system!

This CHF 1,000,000 grant (Jan 2025 - Dec 2026) will fund a state-of-the-art mass spectrometry imaging platform that enables fast and high-sensitivity spatial metabolomics. The new equipment will significantly enhance our capabilities for spatial lipidomics research and support our ongoing projects on brain lipid architecture.

This shared equipment will benefit multiple research groups at EPFL working on spatial metabolomics applications.
